abstract: Rather than challenging new forms of peer-to-peer commerce, like Airbnb or Uber, government should foster the kind of self-regulation that prevails in many established industries and professions, an economist writes.
snippet: Rather than challenging new forms of peer-to-peer commerce, like Airbnb or Uber, government should foster the kind of self-regulation that prevails in many established industries and professions, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Arun Sundararajan is a professor and NEC Faculty Fellow in the Stern School of Business at New York University, where his research studies how digital technologies transform business and society. His research has been supported by organizations that include Google, IBM, Microsoft and Yahoo.

headline.main: Trusting the ‘Sharing Economy’ to Regulate Itself
